content.description:
Follow the finger crack making use of side-pulls and underclings through the two small bulges. The crux is protected by a small nut.

The thin crack on the face left of the Squeaking Pikas chimney
Small to medium nuts, cams to 2", and webbing for a boulder anchor

Fun stemming up a short chimney. Avoid the loose stack of talus in the ceiling by exiting left onto the face. Belay from a slung boulder.

Head straight up the talus slope to find a left-facing chimney left of the main face
Few cams to 1", #4, (optional #6 for easier ground), and 8m webbing for a boulder anchor

The flaring chimney cutting the main overhanging buttress. Either start at the overhanging crack through a juggy boulder problem (V1) or up the easier ground to the left and traverse in. Enter the flaring chimney and work through multiple overhangs and many good ledges. Take care not to send stacks of loose talus down on your belayer when topping out, and bring at least 8m of webbing to sling a large flat boulder at the top.

Starts at the bottom of the obvious flaring chimney at the tallest point of the cliff
cams to 4" and 8m webbing for boulder anchor

An alpine climbing area on a greenstone cliff band in a wonderful position on top of Keno Hill. Although freeze-thaw cycles have fractured most of the stone into a wide talus field, a few routes can be found on sections of intact cliffs. There are no bolts anywhere, but boulders can be found at the top of the cliff to be slung using long lengths of webbing.  
Note that snow persists on the talus well into August.
63° 56’ 27” N 135° 13’ 23” W
